title: Content-length bug introduced in 0.12.16: Timeouts on redirected POST request
body:
## What happend

After upgrading from reqwest 0.12.15 to 0.12.16, a blocking clients call (with cookie jar and redirects enabled):

```rust
client.post(url)
      .form(&form_data)
      .send()?
```

against our SSO API hangs indefinitely and eventually errors with a timeout on the GET request that is caused by the server returning 302 on the POST:

```
error sending request for url (https://redacted.example.com/idp/profile/SAML2/Redirect/SSO?execution=e1s1)

Caused by:
    operation timed out
```

The same code using reqwest 0.12.15 worked without issues.

## The bug
A POST request that receives a redirect is followed by a GET request that incorrectly includes a Content-Length header with the original POST length. 
I imagine this makes the server wait forever, never receiving the non-existent the body causing the timeout. Using a local proxy confirms this: `HTTP/1 protocol error: peer closed connection without sending complete message body (received 0 bytes, expected 360)`

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/254fc282-a084-4796-bba3-078976ca8331)

## Environment
* OS: Windows 10
* reqwest v0.12.16 with features: `blocking`, `cookies`, `gzip`, `rustls-tls` (Tested: The issue still occurs in 0.12.18)
* Rust 1.87.0 

## Protocol Violation
I think this is essentially a violation of the [HTTP/1.1 spec](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7230#section-3.3.2):
> A user agent SHOULD NOT send a Content-Length header field when the request message does not contain a payload body and the method semantics do not anticipate such a body.

In this case the GET is such a method, where no body is anticipated.
